title.value: Cross-sectional and longitudinal neuroanatomical profiles of distinct clinical (adaptive) outcomes in autism
title.justification: This title provides a clear and concise description of the study conducted in the paper.
title.quote: Cross-sectional and longitudinal neuroanatomical profiles of distinct clinical (adaptive) outcomes in autism

extractions.description: This paper investigates the cross-sectional and longitudinal neuroanatomical correlates of distinct clinical (adaptive) outcomes in individuals with autism spectrum disorder (ASD) using a longitudinal follow-up study. The study examines how adaptive behavior in individuals with ASD is linked to variations in neuroanatomy, and explores potential genomic associates of these neuroanatomical differences.

type.justification: The study involves the collection and analysis of empirical data from a longitudinal follow-up of individuals with autism and neurotypical controls.
type.quote: We conducted a longitudinal follow-up study of 333 individuals (161 autistic and 172 neurotypical individuals, aged 6–30 years), with two assessment time points separated by ~12–24 months.

name.justification: The study focuses on the neuroanatomical correlates of adaptive behavior in individuals with autism.
name.quote: To pave the way for ‘precision-medicine’ approaches, it is crucial to identify the cross-sectional and, given the developmental nature of autism, longitudinal neurobiological (including neuroanatomical and linked genetic) correlates of this variation.

name.justification: The study explores the potential genomic associates of the observed neuroanatomical differences.
name.quote: Next, we explored the neuroanatomical differences’ potential genomic associates using the Allen Human Brain Atlas.

name.justification: The paper is published in Molecular Psychiatry and addresses autism spectrum disorder, which is a major concern in psychiatric studies.
name.quote: Individuals with autism spectrum disorder (henceforth referred to as autism) display significant variation in clinical outcome.

name.justification: The study uses data from the Longitudinal European Autism Project (LEAP).
name.quote: We leveraged one of the largest deep-phenotyped longitudinal autism datasets worldwide (EU-AIMS Longitudinal European Autism Project [22])

referenced_paper_title.value: The EU-AIMS Longitudinal European Autism Project (LEAP): design and methodologies to identify and validate stratiﬁcation biomarkers for autism spectrum disorders
referenced_paper_title.justification: The quoted sentence provides a clear reference to the LEAP dataset's use.
referenced_paper_title.quote: We leveraged one of the largest deep-phenotyped longitudinal autism datasets worldwide (EU-AIMS Longitudinal European Autism Project [22])

name.justification: The study mentions the use of FreeSurfer for cortical reconstruction.

referenced_paper_title.justification: FreeSurfer is a widely used tool in neuroimaging studies for processing and analyzing brain MRI data, and is explicitly mentioned in the paper.
